title: Computational Thinking and AI Ethics
description: Middle School - Computational thinking and AI ethics

sections.title: What is Computational Thinking?
sections.content: Computational thinking is a problem-solving process that includes decomposition, pattern recognition, abstraction, and algorithms. It's how we break down complex problems into smaller, manageable parts - just like how you might solve a big puzzle by working on smaller sections first!

sections.title: The Four Pillars of Computational Thinking
sections.content: Let's explore the four main components that make computational thinking so powerful for solving problems.

sections.title: 1. Decomposition - Breaking Things Down
sections.content: Decomposition means breaking a big problem into smaller, easier-to-solve pieces. Think of it like taking apart a sandwich to see all its ingredients!

examples.title: Planning a School Event
examples.content:
Big Problem: Organize a school science fair
Smaller Parts:
- Choose a date and location
- Invite participants
- Set up displays
- Arrange judges
- Plan refreshments
- Create awards

examples.title: Creating a Game
examples.content:
Big Problem: Make a fun computer game
Smaller Parts:
- Design characters
- Create game rules
- Build levels
- Add sound effects
- Test for bugs
- Share with friends

sections.title: 2. Pattern Recognition - Finding Similarities
sections.content: Pattern recognition helps us find similarities and trends in data or problems. Once we spot patterns, we can predict what might happen next!

examples.title: Weather Patterns
examples.content: If we notice that it usually rains after cloudy days, we can predict when to bring an umbrella. AI weather systems use this same idea with much more data!

examples.title: Learning Patterns
examples.content: Students often make similar mistakes in math. Teachers can recognize these patterns and create better lessons to help everyone learn.

sections.title: 3. Abstraction - Focusing on What Matters
sections.content: Abstraction means focusing on the most important details and ignoring the less important ones. It's like drawing a simple map that shows only the streets you need, not every single tree!

examples.title: Subway Map
examples.content: A subway map doesn't show every building or street - just the train lines and stations you need to get around. This abstraction makes it much easier to use!

examples.title: Recipe Instructions
examples.content: A recipe tells you the essential steps and ingredients, but doesn't describe every tiny detail like exactly how to hold the spoon. The important parts are abstracted for you.

sections.title: 4. Algorithms - Step-by-Step Solutions
sections.content: An algorithm is a set of step-by-step instructions to solve a problem. It's like a recipe for computers (or people) to follow!

examples.title: Making a Peanut Butter Sandwich
examples.content:
Algorithm:
1. Get two slices of bread
2. Open peanut butter jar
3. Spread peanut butter on one slice
4. Open jelly jar
5. Spread jelly on other slice
6. Put slices together
7. Enjoy your sandwich!

examples.title: Finding the Tallest Student
examples.content:
Algorithm:
1. Line up all students
2. Start with the first student as 'tallest'
3. Compare with next student
4. If next student is taller, they become 'tallest'
5. Repeat until you've checked everyone
6. Announce the tallest student

sections.title: Ethics in AI - Doing the Right Thing
sections.content: As we create AI systems, we must consider their impact on people and society. This includes thinking about fairness, privacy, and responsibility. Just like we have rules for how to treat each other, we need rules for how AI should work!

examples.title: Fair AI Example
examples.content: An AI system that helps teachers grade assignments should treat all students fairly, regardless of their background or previous performance. It should focus only on the quality of the work.

examples.title: Privacy Protection
examples.content: AI systems that use personal information (like photos or messages) should always ask permission first and keep that information safe from people who shouldn't see it.

examples.title: Helpful, Not Harmful
examples.content: AI should be designed to help people, not replace them or make their lives harder. For example, AI tutors should help students learn better, not do their homework for them.

sections.title: Problem-Solving in Action
sections.content: Let's put it all together! When solving problems with computational thinking: 1) Break it down (decomposition), 2) Find patterns, 3) Focus on important details (abstraction), 4) Create step-by-step solutions (algorithms).

examples.title: Organizing Your Backpack
examples.content:
Problem: Your backpack is always messy
Decomposition: Separate by subject, supplies, personal items
Pattern Recognition: Notice which items you use most often
Abstraction: Focus on easy access, not perfect organization
Algorithm: 1) Empty backpack, 2) Group similar items, 3) Put frequently used items in easy spots, 4) Pack everything back neatly

sections.title: Why This Matters for AI
sections.content: Computational thinking is the foundation of how AI works. Every AI system uses these same principles to solve problems, recognize patterns, and make decisions. By learning these skills, you're learning to think like an AI engineer!

learningObjectives: Understand the four pillars of computational thinking
Apply computational thinking to real-world problems
Recognize ethical issues in AI development
Evaluate AI systems for bias and fairness
Understand the importance of privacy in AI
